bestBHT.bht: Jesus affirms that he is the Son of Man and the Son of God, synonymous with the glorified Messiah. In response to the question about being the Son of God, Jesus answers, Ye say (correctly), for I am. This exchange reveals his claim to be the Messiah, Son of Man, and Son of God. Interestingly, Ye say is a Greek idiom that can be understood as a simple affirmative response of Yes.

Henry Alford: The Son of God used as synonymous with the Son of Man sitting on the right hand of the power of God, i.e. with the glorified Messiah.
Worth observing... the Son of God used as synonymous with the Son of Man sitting on the right hand of the power of God.
Philip Schaff: Luke 22:70. The next question shows that they understood Him aright. His answer may be rendered: Ye say that I am, or, ‘ye say (correctly), for I am.’
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus affirms that he is the Son of Man and will sit at the right hand of the power of God."
Jesus accepts the challenge and admits that he claims to be all three (Messiah, the Son of man, the Son of God).
Ye say (Hυμεις λεγετε). Just a Greek idiom for 'Yes'.
John Gill: Art thou the Son of God? ... it is the very truth: 'for I am'."
Ye say that I am; ... it is the very truth: 'for I am'."
Ye say it, and ye say right; ... it is the very truth: 'for I am'.
John Wesley: Art thou then the Son of God?" - Both these, the Son of God, and the Son of man, were known titles of the Messiah.
The Son of God" - Taken from his Divine nature.
The Son of man" - Taken from his human nature.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus is affirming that he is the Son of Man and the Son of God, synonymous with the glorified Messiah. He acknowledges that he will sit at the right hand of the power of God, confirming the truth of their questioning. When asked if he is the Son of God, Jesus responds by saying, Ye say (correctly), for I am. This exchange reveals that Jesus claims to be all three - Messiah, Son of Man, and Son of God. It is worth noting that Ye say is just a Greek idiom for Yes.

Jesus confirms that he is the Son of Man and the Son of God, synonymous with the glorified Messiah. He acknowledges his future position at the right hand of the power of God. In response to the question about being the Son of God, Jesus answers, Ye say (correctly), for I am, asserting the truth of their statement. This exchange reveals his claim to be the Messiah, Son of Man, and Son of God. The phrase Ye say is simply a Greek idiom for Yes.

This exchange reveals his claim to be the Messiah, Son of Man, and Son of God. The phrase Ye say is a Greek idiom meaning Yes.

Jesus affirms that he is the Son of Man and utters the phrase Ye say (correctly), for I am, acknowledging the truth in their statement. This response reveals his claim to be the Messiah, Son of Man, and Son of God, synonymous with the glorified Messiah. It is noteworthy that Ye say is a Greek idiom meaning Yes.

Jesus affirms that he is the Son of Man and the Son of God, synonymous with the glorified Messiah. In response to the question about being the Son of God, Jesus answers, Ye say (correctly), for I am. This exchange reveals his claim to be the Messiah, Son of Man, and Son of God. Interestingly, Ye say is a Greek idiom that can be understood as a simple affirmative response of Yes.
